reviewText: I can be in the worst mood ever and as soon as I put in this DVD and start doing the warm-ups I have a smile on my face. I don't know what it is, but it works. The music is fantastic! I love the warm-up for this one and also the hip opening sequence. The presets are great if you want to target a certain area or you are short on time:Quick Bliss (20 min)Quick Hips (30 min)Mood Uplift Workout (40 min)Hip Release/Heart Opening (45 min)I like the Quick Hips and Hip Release/Heart Opening the best. When my hips are loosened up I just feel like I can move forward through my day better. I love this one for those days when I am feeling a little low and in need of a pick-me-up or for a shorter workout when I don't have the energy for anything too rigorous.

reviewText: This is by far one of my favorite Ravi and Ana dvds! What an amazing mood uplifter this is! I personally think this is one of their most fun workouts and it was a great hip opener! My hips have never felt better! The sequence for the hip opener is relatively short (15 minutes or so), but what amazing results in such a short period of time! You will feel the results instantly, and with regular use the results will be more long term!This dvd is well worth the money! It is great for beginners-advanced and it is just plain fun! This workout flies by and you will be left with a very positive, clear mind and a great overall body workout! Also I personally enjoyed the cardio in this video! An amazing buy for anyone who loves Ravi and Ana or just enjoys a FUN, EFFECTIVE, MOOD ENHANCING workout! I LOVE it! :-)
summary: I truly felt happier and less stressed after this great workout!

reviewText: In my opinion, this is one of the top 2 Ravi and Ana DVDS.  It has the catchiest songs and doesn't do at much of the funky wave your arms in the air.  It does have some lovely hip and waist movements that are fun.  I really like everything about this particular DVD, esepcially that it has 4 alternate workouts on a menu - not all of their DVDs have programmed workouts for you. You don't have to skip around the main menu function if you want a shorter or more focused workout.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I highly, highly, highly, highly recommend everyone to get this DVD!!!! While I adore and love ALL of Ana & Ravi's DVDs (I have yet to find a bad thing to say about them, it's hard to say something bad when you feel so light on your feet and full of radiant happiness), this is definitely at the top of my list of all of their's. I had purchased this DVD and forgot I owned it for months. I was pulling an all-nighter studying (after starting the day at 6 am for work) and realized that I needed energy, and I needed it quickly! At 1 am I pulled this DVD out, blew the dust off of it and began my journey. This was the very first time I had experienced Kundalini Rising, seeing several strange lights when I was meditating. I was freaked out at first and called a good friend of mine who is a Kundalini teacher, and she explained the situation. It wasn't a bad sensation, quite the opposite, it felt AMAZING! I felt like everything in my body had opened up to a whole new awareness and best, I felt powerful and strong! This is what Kundalini does, this is just the first time I had ever felt it. Also, I am a long-distance runner, so this DVD helps me to strengthen my hip flexors in much different methods than one would think. There aren't many moves on here that are you standard hip openers, but it definitely does open the hips up! The first night I did this I ended up completing my all-nighter around 5 am, with energy to spare! Thank you, again, Ana and Ravi!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am new to Kundalini Yoga, having just heard of it three months ago. In that time, I have purchased DVD's by Raviana, Maya Feinnes, & Gurmukh (I apologize I I misspelled the last two, I wasn't impressed enough to look them up and get them correct!). The Raviana Kundalini Yoga DVD's have been, by far, my favorite, and I make it a point to practice Kundalini Yoga twice a week (I do regular workouts the other 5 days) and do their PM Yoga DVD each night before I go to bed to help me release the day and sleep better without sleep aids. I've had a lot of job related stress lately and it's been a lifesaver.Now, on to this particular DVD. I hold a lot of tension in my hips. I've had a sore hip for about 10 years and thought I had arthritis. I'm to the point where I can't take anti-inflammatory medications any longer due to medical concerns and thought I'd have to live with the pain. That is until I figured out that the pain is muscular in nature, and through extended stretching, I can make it go away. This DVD is very beneficial in that regard as it opens up all the hip joints and contains a 10 or 15 minute segment that focuses solely on the hips. After a couple of months I no longer have tight hip flexors and my psoas muscle is flexible. I still need daily work on my tight hamstrings and IT band, but they are coming along. My hip no longer throbs when I sit too long, and when I do get pain, I know the stretches.I typically do the entire DVD first thing in the AM, however if I need a quick stretch I use the matrix function and just do a quick workout. This is a very enjoyable DVD and I always feel uplifted and energetic after I complete it. The instruction is good, and Ana & Ravi are pleasant to listen to.

reviewText: This is a really nice balance between meditations and intensity of the workout. From a few DVD's that I have by Ravi and Ana, I would say this is moderate level of activity. LOVE IT!

reviewText: Of all of the Ravi and Ana releases, this one seems to be the one people have complained about the most.  By the title, many seemed to be convinced that they would be getting a very intense hip opening session.  While they do have exercises that release the hips, buttocks, psoas and hamstrings, it isn't the most exhaustive hip opening segment I've ever used.  And that's okay.A disclaimer first: My hip joints are naturally pretty loose.  While my muscles are as prone to stiffness as anyone else's, I can get away with a lot of postures that many others struggle with.  Keeping those in mind, I found the postures used in the hip opening segments to be just what I needed- enough to get into my muscles, but not so much that I'm bored and wondering if we're there yet.  I've read a lot of comments elsewhere on the internet grumbling that they wanted more.  As a yoga instructor, I feel like this is a wonderful practice that, with consistency, will loosen up the lower body and even the abdominals.  I'm always very nervous when I see a practice (yoga or otherwise) that spends a lot of time on, say, the groin or hamstrings or outer thighs.  I view such unbalanced practices the same way I do cracking your neck or spine- it feels good at the time, but you're probably only making it worse in the long run.The mood mastery sets and meditations are surprisingly strenuous.  The idea here seems to be to work both the body and the breathing to the point of tension before creating the space for release.  I have to admit, while I find this effective, I do find it unpleasant enough as I go through it that I don't end up reaching for those sections too often.That having been said, I do think this is a good release to use in conjunction with the more lower-body intensive Yoga Beauty Body and Beginners and Beyond- it's just not the love fest I usually have with their other releases.
summary: Nice release for hips and body
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love to do this DVD before I start the week...it helps prepare me for the week ahead. The hips relate to moving forward in life and so in opening the hips, it releases fears and blockages and helps you to move forward in your life as well as feeling great to your body! It also has the So Darshan Chakra Kriya(meditation with breathing and naval pumping) which is wonderful for dealing with any emotions and working through them. Whenever I'm feeling resistance to things ahead in my life, I do this DVD, and it's amazing the freedom and peace it brings. It opens you up on a subtle level...the exercises aren't difficult or overly stretching, but they work on a deep level...physically and emotionally.
summary: great DVD for moving forward in life

reviewText: I have 5 DVDs by Ana and Ravi and am a big fan. I rotate and do them a few times a week, mixed in with my other workout routines. My favorite still is the Fat Free Yoga which is by far one of the best DVDs by the couple, a second favorite which is a close tie is the Warrior Workout. This DVD is very relaxing for the hips and I would rate it as a moderate workout, best to follow a cardio or for more mellow days, and may work better in evenings than mornings.

reviewText: I have an extensive background in kundalini yoga, dance, and meditation. To me, these are the best at home kundalini yoga classes. I have most of Ana & Ravi's yoga dvd's and this one is one of my favorites. Their production gets better each time, but I do like the more dense format of some of the earlier dvd's (around the time of Yoga Bliss Hips). I love the customized matrix option as well. I use it more than I thought I would.For me, the highlights of all of their dvd's are the specific medicinal notes, which allows me to work on specific glands or physical issues by learning which poses effects the body in different ways. They seem very well organized to me.

reviewText: I love love love Ana & Ravi's DVDs. I own six so far, including this one, which I bought on streaming instead of an actual disc. So far, it has stopped repeatedly every time I've played it, which I think is a problem with Amazon's player. I only mention it in case you're on the fence about streaming vs. DVD. Aside from that, I couldn't recommend this DVD more highly!What makes their DVDs so extraordinary is a combination of the pacing, the demonstrations/explanations, and the affirmations they share throughout. I find myself using the mantras they've taught me throughout my day, alleviating stress with the breathing techniques they use in the video, and reminding myself to "do my best and be so blessed." Theirs are by far the best workout videos I have ever used, and I would strongly recommend them to anyone-- regardless of yoga experience or fitness level.
summary: LOVE this workout-- wish I'd gotten the DVD instead of streaming.

reviewText: It's tough, but Ravi Singh and Ana Brett manage to constantly come up with new twists on Kundalini Yoga.  I just had to buy this DVD because of the name.  The DVD does not disappoint.The premise of this DVD is that tightness in the hips can prevent one from moving forward in life.  It can mean that you're afraid to try something new.  Whether or not you believe this, if you do the exercises on this DVD, your hips and hamstrings will thank you.What I particularly enjoyed about this workout:**the breath primer was part of the workout and not a separate chapter at the end.  The breath primer has you practicing long, deep breathing and the breath of fire.  For me, it's a perfect way to get into the spirit of Kundalini yoga.**the clean, uncluttered set design.  Ana is working out against a white background.  She is doing the exercises on a small pink rug, which is at the center of a large yellow flower.  I mention the background as a real positive since their subsequent DVDs are set against a very fake looking outdoor background.**the short meditation pauses after every few exercises.  These really help get me centered.**the nice hip stretches.  I do a lot of intense cardio and tend to skip the stretching, so these stretches are just the thing.**the warm-up exercises for camel pose are great for posture.  You clasp your hands behind your back and stretch backwards.  I sit hunched over a computer all day and this stretch feels great.A few things to note on this DVD. These things don't detract from the wonderful workout, but they're worth mentioning.The things:**Ana's voice is much louder during the breath primer section and I always have to lower the volume. Her voice is nice and subdued during her other sections.**the somewhat long (6 minute) cat-cow pose.  At least you're doing different variations of cat-cow, so it doesn't seem so long.**the laughing section.  You lie down and begin to laugh out loud.  I still feel somewhat self-conscious doing this, but I do it and always feel better afterwards.**the inaccurate workout time.  The DVD jacket says this workout is 60 minutes; in fact, it's 75 minutes.  There are 60 minutes of exercises and then 15 minutes of meditation.I highly recommend this DVD to anyone wanting to feel the energizing, yet relaxing power of Kundalini yoga.  This DVD is suitable for people of all fitness levels.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Most people seem to be reviewing the old Yoga Bliss Hips which I owned and loved as well. I thought I should give a review for the newly Matrixed version. You can just work mainly your core and upper body if you want to work on the "Bliss" aspect of it. Or you can work your core and hips and work on your flexibility and creativity! Ana & Ravi tell us on this this DVD that when you open your hips it helps release fear and lets you be unafraid to express your personal style? It's true! And it works!It's a magical wonderful DVD. Full of the Kundalini Yoga goodness I have come to love and crave!
summary: I Love the new Matrix Yoga Bliss Hips!

reviewText: Yes, I can not believe that this is another great hit and like many other writers on this dvd it has become of my favourite one, to date (still waiting for the delivery of the new ones that have just come out).  It is great that the dvd is broken down to four main workouts (two full 45 minutes and 2 shorter ones at under 20 minutes).  I use the long work outs during the weekend, and I may mix in a shorter workout from another dvd, like the total cleanse.  My body is sure worth the care.  There are always the modified forms and I am still aiming to at least do the full exercise without too many rest moments.  None-the-less, I am sweating plenty and I know I had a great workout ( i am in pretty good shape) so dont be fooled that you are not getting a workout.  Your Are! A great dvd for both beginners and yogis.Also, the work out is also addresses emotional issues/depression/ and with the hectic life style and demanding work place, I know I have benefited from being a lot calmer in dealing with the day to day pressures.  Like many of the writers, below, I have become a kundalini/ana & ravi fan - it is the only form of yoga that I actually look forward to doing, actually find time to do, see great results in myself both physically, mentally and spiritually, and cheaper than belonging to the gym!  I am a seeker and this is one excellent form of exercise even for those who are not spiritually inclined (although it helps if you are.)

reviewText: This review will have a two-part format.  In the first part, I'll describe the contents of the DVD as well as my thoughts on them.  In the second part, I'll say some more general things about Ana and Ravi and kundalini yoga.  It seems the negative reviews of their DVDs come mainly from people who didn't know what to expect when ordering kundalini yoga DVDs -- because they ARE a little bit different from what you're used to, if you've only practiced hatha yoga in the past.  I am unabashedly an Ana and Ravi fan, but hopefully my evaluation will help you make the correct decision for yourself, even if your opinion happens not to be the same as mine.----------Part I----------Like most of Ana and Ravi's DVDs, Yoga Bliss Hips has the matrix menu which allows you to customize the length of your workout.  All exercises in this DVD are done equally on both sides of the body.Tune In (2:46): This segment is similar/the same in many of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs; you sit cross-legged, focus on your breathing, and chant "ong namo guru dev namo" three times.Breath Primer (4:38): Please note that this segment may not play if you just play the entire DVD through.  It is accessible from the matrix menu and the chapter selection menu, however.  If you are not familiar with kundalini yoga, you will definitely want to follow along here.  It's actually a pretty good refresher for anyone who has practiced for awhile, as well.  You learn how to do long deep breathing, a panting breath that serves as an introduction to breath of fire, and then a standard breath of fire technique.Energy Warm-Ups (12:44): This is a rather long warm up for one of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs, and consists of the following exercises.*Sit cross-legged and grind your stomach in a circle.*Clasp your hands together over your head and move your head back and forth in time with your breathing.*Circle your head around.*A cat/cow series with different breath patterns and speeds.Hip Opening Set (17:02): This is a fairly long set, as well, but it goes by very quickly for me.  (I need work on my hips due to some sciatica issues so I've been doing this one a lot lately.)  It consists of the following exercises.*Crow (or frog) pose with breath of fire*Butterfly with long deep breathing*Sitting cross-legged with one leg over the left and leaning forward with long deep breathing*Downward-facing dog with breath of fire*Lunge pose with long deep breathing*A forward bend with the legs about 2.5-3 feet apart with breath of fire*After repeating from downward dog on the other side, a longer downward dog with long deep breathingMood Mastery Set (15:40): This one has some elements that may seem strange to people not familiar with Ana's and Ravi's DVDs.  It consists of the following exercises.*Sitting on your knees with your hands in bear grip, press your hands into your navel holding the breath in and out*Sat kriya (this would take a lot of space to explain, so if you're unfamiliar, Google it)*Lean back on your elbows and raise and lower your legs to the rhythm of the breath of fire*Lie on your back and laugh (this is one exercise that got some complaints; some studies have shown that laughter can improve mood and even help deal with pain, and I assume that's the point of this one)*Sit up with your legs crossed, make fists with your hands, and punch while holding your breath (another mood exercise)*An exercise where you inhale and raise your shoulders, exhale and lower your shoulders, inhale and flex your chest forward, exhale and flex your chest back (and repeat)Heart Center Set (8:52): This set consists of the following exercises.*Inhale and raise your arms in front of you, exhale and lower them*Hold onto your ribs (that is, hug yourself) and twist left and right, coordinated with your breathing*Sitting on your knees, interlace your hands behind your back; rise up off your heels and open your eyes, leaning back slightly; sit back down on your heels, head to the floor, with your arms -- still interlaced -- raised off your back and your eyes closed*Camel pose with breath of fire*Meditate in a bowing pose with your palms together*Sit with your palms in your lap; raise your hands above your head with your palms up and inhale, then bring your palms back down and exhale (this is fairly fast)Deep Relaxation (2:44): This is similar in many of Ravi's and Ana's DVDs.  Lie on your back, slow your breathing, and listen to Ravi.Breath Meditation (3:48): Sit cross-legged with your fingertips meeting each other, palms apart and fingers spread wide.  This exercise is then simply breathing in, holding, and exhaling.Sodarshan Chakra Kriya (7:18): Block your right nostril and inhale through your left nostril.  Pump your stomach to a given rhythm.  Exhale through your right nostril.  I find this difficult to complete and sometimes actually have to stop and pant a bit before moving on.  I'm trying to work up to doing it the whole way through.Closing Prayer (2:38): This is similar to what appears in other Ravi/Ana DVDs.For those of you familiar with Ravi's and Ana's DVDs, this is one of the ones with the pink circle rug and flower pattern on the floor, the white background, and dark-haired Ana.  I've noticed a lot of the music in those overlaps, as do some of Ana's outfits.  You may have seen some of the hip opening set in the "so long sciatica" segment of Yoga Quick Fixes.  Both Ravi and Ana narrate and Ana demonstrates the poses and movements.  This DVD does not have any mantra chanting (performed by the participants at home) other than the "tune in" and "closing prayer" sections.I've been focusing mainly on the hip opening set because, as I think I mentioned earlier, I have some issues with sciatica.  I do this set first thing in the morning and it really helps me work out the stiffness and get moving.  Don't forget, though -- this DVD is not ONLY for hips.  "Bliss" is also in the title, hence the heart center and mood mastery sets.  In covering a lot of bases, you do get lower body and upper body work, as well as a bit of core work (if you have time to do the whole DVD).One warning: sometimes doing too much cat/cow every day, for a long period of time, can cause my wrists to hurt a bit.  So if you have wrist issues, don't do the warm-up segment every day.I think this is probably not my very favorite DVD that Ravi and Ana have put out (I have about 2/3 of their DVDs), but I still rate it very highly.  The first segment (hip opening) and the warm-ups would be good for beginners.  The other segments may be best for intermediate/advanced practitioners.  Ana and Ravi do offer some suggestions for modifications of certain poses.  And don't forget -- you don't have to keep up with Ana.  Work at your own pace.----------Part II----------Now, on to a more general discussion of kundalini yoga in general, and Ana's and Ravi's DVDs in particular.Most of the yoga that people are familiar with falls under the umbrella of hatha yoga.  Perhaps you've done a series of static poses, or some vinyasa/flow yoga.  Kundalini yoga is not exactly like either of these, although Ana's and Ravi's DVDs do incorporate elements of hatha yoga (e.g., this DVD has a lot of downward dog in it).  However, kundalini yoga is also what I would consider to be a very active form of yoga, consisting of some repeated movements and a lot more work with the breath than you may be used to.  It can be difficult to keep up with at first, but can be very rewarding if you stick with it.  If you are bored of holding static poses all the time, or if you want a bit more movement but hate vinyasa (sorry, but I am not a fan of flow yoga), kundalini might really work well for you.  And, as I said earlier, use the modifications Ana and Ravi discuss if you need to use them.  Yes, Ana is fit (and this makes her an excellent demonstrator for the poses), but this is not a competition.  Don't strain yourself, and don't try to keep up with her.  Just try to improve a little bit every time!Kundalini yoga also involves a lot of meditation.  Sometimes this is quiet and involves breathing either in a sitting position or lying down, occasionally with your hands in a mudra (hand position).  Sometimes it involves chanting a mantra.  This DVD does not contain much in the way of chanting except in the opening and closing segments.  Whenever there are mantras, Ana and Ravi tell you what they mean.  If you are uncomfortable with mantras for religious reasons, check out Ana's and Ravi's website (can't post links in reviews but they're easy to find through Google) for alternatives.With respect to calorie-burning, this is probably not the sort of program that will make you shed a ton of weight.  What it is good for, is improving your mood and your flexibility.  And as a physical activity, it does burn some calories and strengthen some parts of your body.  But kundalini yoga works on your inner self as well as your outer self, and so some parts are a little less "active" than others.  For my own part, I still do plenty of pretty intense cardio at other times of the day.Ana's outfits are a bit skimpy, but certainly nothing less than you would see at the beach.  And the reason she dresses like she does is so that you can really see her performing the movements and asanas.  That way you know exactly how to position yourself for maximum benefit.  (Most of the time, kundalini yoga is done with the eyes closed, anyway.)  There is not a lot in the way of initial instruction in this DVD.  If you are familiar with Ana's and Ravi's work, you can jump right in.  But if you are new to kundalini yoga, watch it first.  Observe Ana, listen to the cues, make sure you understand.  You'll be glad for the lack of excessive instruction later -- you don't want to be told on the 20th time you do a DVD how to do downward dog; you know it by this point!Some health claims are made in this DVD.  Take those with a grain of salt.  I find that Ana and Ravi are quite accurate when it comes to muscular and skeletal issues (like my sciatica).  I don't know that I believe everything they say about the glands, however, for example.  Perhaps that's my Ph.D. in chemistry intruding.  At any rate, certainly don't use yoga as a substitute for seeing the doctor.  But doing a routine like this isn't likely to hurt you or make your health condition worse (as long as you PACE YOURSELF).If you are struggling with a pose, or don't feel there's an adequate explanation, Ravi and Ana are very accessible and quite nice.  They have contact information on their website (the URL is on the DVD case) and usually get back to you in a couple of days.  They also have a monthly e-mail newsletter that I enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I got this along with their Ultimate Stretch Workout, because I wanted to increase my flexibility. Both titles worked wonders. The approach here is more than skin deep: a great physical workout, but also so much more! The subtitle: hip opening and mood mastery says it all. There is so much of the generic in yoga and fitness. To have actually found an approach which makes connections like the Ana & Ravi titles, between emotions and energy blocks, body and mind, self-concept and external outcomes, is really a revelation. It seems that I've been waiting for something like this for a long time and I'm very happy to announce that it's finally arrived!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Being the compulsive shopper that i sometimes am, I clicked on BlissHips as a 'buy together' dvd when purchasing Yoga Beauty Body as birthday present for my girlfriend. Suffice it to say I sort of kept this one for myself after I tried it! I thought this would be too girly for me  as I didn't really think - my hips needed opening?(what's that about?) ...but i felt completely amazing! after having finished the set.This is a fun, high energy workout that works somehow on an emotional level as well as a physical one. I usually still feel serene for a couple of days after having completed the work-out. A definite two thumbs up. Also, the matrix is great because I can pre-program the workout to include whatever sets i want to do in whichever order I like.

reviewText: Another awesome yoga video from Ana and Ravi. Both my husband and myself enjoy Bliss hips. It will get you warm and flowing from your belly button to your thighs, plus, all that breathwork pumps your energy and puts you in a great mood. We love this one. Beginner to advanced beginner.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Every year, Ravi and Ana release 3 DVD's.  To me there is always 1 in the group that doesn't totally do it for me.  This one is it.  I am disappointed with the hip opening set.  It is meager.  There are only 2 hip opening exercises with no prep in the warm-up. The two exercises are double pigeon and deep lunge.  That's it.  Now, they should have put in crow or table squat in the warm-ups.  How about butterfly.  But double pigeon as the first hip opener. That's too hard for most people myself included.  I was expecting so much more for this set.  How about wide legged pose, reclining pigeon? Yogic squats standing and squating.  I know that there is a kundalini yoga set especially for hips.  I've done it!!! Sorry guys you missed the boat on this yoga set.  If you want a hip opening set, buy Rodney Yee's Advanced yoga DVD, or use a warm up from other RaviAna DVD's (i.e.ultimate stretch).  As for the Beat depression and heart opening sets, I only viewed those, it appears that these sets are the strong points of this DVD.Another pet peeve.  I didn't notice it on the Dance the Chakra workout, but the breath primer is after the Tune In, which means after viewing it once, you have to hit next on your remote to go to the warm-up. It kind of breaks up the flow.I viewed the Body Beauty DVD and it looks yummy.  2 out of 3 ain't bad.

reviewText: This DVD will lift your spirits, as you open up those hips!!!
